Technical Assistance for  
Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice President  G. van der Linden, Knowledge Management and Sustainable

Director General  B. Lohani, Regional and Sustainable Development Department (RSDD)

Team leader  A. Akanda, Principal Safeguard Specialist, Environment and Social

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognize 
the need for strengthened social and environmental safeguard systems. Consultations in the 
context  of  the  middle  income  and  ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR)  country  partnership 
framework1 and the innovation and efficiency initiative (IEI)2 have highlighted the need to 
increase  country  ownership  and  capacity  in  delivering  safeguard  outcomes,  and  to  adopt 
safeguard  procedures  that  reflect  the  varying  capacities  of  DMCs.  Ongoing  multilateral 
development bank harmonization efforts3 encourage development partners to harmonize their 
practices and procedures around more effective country safeguard systems. As part of ADB’s 
ongoing reform agenda and renewed commitment to improving development effectiveness, a 
safeguard policy update is being undertaken to ensure that ADB safeguard policies remain 
relevant to changing client needs and to new lending modalities and instruments. The update 
will explore several areas to strengthen implementation of the policies, including the possible 
application of country safeguard systems where relevant safeguard frameworks and capacities 
exist.  
 
2.  The  scope  and  direction  of  the  proposed  ADB  technical  assistance  (TA)  grant  for 
Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems were defined in the concept paper approved by ADB 
Management on 18 April 2005. The TA is included in the 2005 TA program of the Regional and 
Sustainable Development Department. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Safeguard policies are generally understood to be operational policies that seek to avoid, 
minimize,  or  mitigate  adverse  environmental  impacts,  social  costs  to  third  parties,  or 
marginalization of vulnerable groups that may result from development projects. Aside from the 
“do no harm” principle, safeguard policies are intended to improve the quality and effectiveness 
of  projects,  and  thus  ensure  sustainable  economic  development.  Although  ADB  has  had 
environment assessment requirements for more than 20 years, its current safeguard policy 
framework  consists  of  three  operational  policies:  Environment  Policy  (2002),  Policy  on 
Indigenous  Peoples  (1998),  and  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995).  These  have 
Operations Manual (OM) sections (F1, F2, F3) and guidelines (Guidelines on Environment 
Assessment [2003], Handbook on Resettlement, and the forthcoming Handbook on Indigenous 
Peoples Policy).  
 
4.  To ensure sustainable development activities, DMCs have adopted safeguard policies, 
and regulatory and administrative frameworks in varying degrees. The development of country 
safeguard frameworks is still evolving. It requires substantial technical support and guidance in 
adopting international best practices and in reaching all sectors and activities. In addition, 
DMCs’  capabilities  in  developing,  applying,  and  implementing  safeguard  systems  vary 
considerably. In countries that have limited resources and institutional capacities, the structured 
development of national safeguard policies and institutional mechanisms requires significant 
policy adjustments, followed by institutional and administrative frameworks that enhance the 
awareness, understanding, and enforcement of the safeguards. An example of the initiation of

2   
that process has been demonstrated in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, which had to 
undertake an adjustment process associated with safeguards that addresses, among others, 
the country’s complex interplay of fragile ecosystems, diverse ethnic groups, and largely state- 
and community-vested property rights.4  
 
5.  In the large DMCs, the need for effective safeguard systems is even more pressing, 
given the widely varying environmental conditions, cultural diversity, and legal and institutional 
complexities. Some of those countries, such as India and the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 
have made significant progress in setting up safeguard systems that are generally consistent 
with international best practices. In India, safeguard policies include well-defined environmental 
assessment procedures, national and state land acquisition and compensation frameworks, and 
tribal and scheduled-caste development programs. Indian state and national agencies have also 
concomitantly developed capacities to apply the safeguards; the National Highways Authority 
and Power Grid Corporation, for example, have set up social and environmental divisions that 
cover all investment activities. The PRC has paid considerable attention to developing state and 
provincial capabilities in applying safeguard policies, especially in highway projects, in which the 
Department of Communications has clearly applied the State Environment Protection Agency’s 
guidelines. However, even in those larger economies, safeguard systems need to be applied 
more  effectively  across  all  sectors.  This  requires  a  closer  understanding  of  gaps  and 
inconsistencies in investment activities financed by external agencies, which are required to 
apply their own safeguard policies.  
 
6.  In consultations and feedback from operational activities, DMCs have indicated that 
although  ADB’s  safeguard  objectives  and  principles  are  generally  acceptable,  the  desired 
outcomes could be achieved by relying on their own country safeguard systems rather than on 
ADB  procedures,  which  in  being  applied  uniformly  across  sectors  and  projects,  do  not 
adequately distinguish among the various frameworks, implementation capacities, and track 
record in different DMCs. DMCs consider that applying safeguard systems based on country-
specific frameworks will reduce transaction costs in project processing and implementation. It 
will also enable them to build institutional capacity and responsiveness to external financing 
requirements across sectors, and at the national and subnational levels. The basic rationale for 
adopting country systems includes (i) scaling up development impact beyond the confines of the 
individual  “ring-fenced”  project,  (ii)  increasing  country  ownership  and  sustainability,  (iii) 
facilitating harmonization, and (iv) simplifying and reducing transaction costs.  
 
7.  The application of country systems involves greater dependence on a country’s existing 
policies and practices when those are equivalent in intent, spirit, and content to ADB’s policies.5 
ADB’s policies do not explicitly refer to the use of country safeguard systems, but efforts are 
made during project processing to ensure general consistency between the policy applications 
(resettlement plans, indigenous peoples development plans, environment management plans) 
and the laws, policies, procedures, and practices of the country where the project is located. 
Nonetheless, a more detailed assessment of country situations and institutional capabilities in 
developing and enforcing safeguard provisions is required to determine the usefulness, extent, 
and practicality of applying a country systems approach. Agreement on the approach and 
applicability  of  country  systems  needs  an  analysis  of  (i)  the  degree  of  commonality

5  Country systems may be considered as those laws, policies, regulations, and administrative structures that are 
used in a particular country for application to an ADB-financed development activity, and have been determined to

3
(“equivalence”) between country safeguard systems and ADB safeguard policies; and (ii) a 
DMC’s  capacity  (“acceptability”)  to  implement  country  safeguard  systems,  in  terms  of 
implementation practices, track record, and the capacity of relevant national, subnational, and 
sector institutions.  
 
8.  The need to harmonize safeguard practices not only between ADB and its DMCs, but 
also across multilateral financial institutions is central to examining a country systems approach. 
Hence,  ADB  and  its  development  partners  will  need  to  coordinate  closely  to  ensure  that 
approaches are consistent. This will avoid the possibility of multiple and varying practices in 
applying country safeguard systems.6 Collaborating with the World Bank, in particular, will 
continue efforts to harmonize approaches to using country safeguard systems.7  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA will improve the implementation of environment and social safeguards through 
strengthened country safeguard systems in DMCs. The TA’s primary purpose is to set out the 
approach and methodology for assessing the potential application of country safeguard systems 
through detailed assessments of safeguard systems in DMCs to identify areas of commonality 
and gaps that will require capacity building, policy adaptation, and improved procedural clarity 
and definition. The assessments will not only support more effective planning of safeguard 
applications, but will also allow greater focus on achieving more effective implementation. The 
emphasis will be on setting out characteristics of country safeguard systems through a typology 
of levels of preparedness and capacity in selected countries. Given the large differences in 
DMCs’ levels of legal and institutional development, the assessments will require identification 
and analyses of policy and procedural gaps with respect to the objectives of ADB safeguard 
policies. An important perspective will be to establish how ADB can be responsive to the 
changing circumstances in DMCs, and enable those DMCs to benefit by improving their own 
safeguard systems. DMCs can increase development investment opportunities and minimize 
social and environmental risks. In identifying ambiguities and inconsistencies across current 
safeguards within DMCs and ADB, project teams and executing agencies are expected to have 
a better understanding of, and increased capability in, implementing social and environmental 
safeguards. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will involve (i) country and thematic analytical studies, (ii) a series of country and 
regional  consultations,  and  (iii)  expert  reviews.  The  TA  will  (i)  develop  a  methodological 
framework for assessing country safeguard systems in selected countries, reflecting the varying 
capacities of DMCs in planning and implementing safeguards; (ii) identify practical approaches 
to developing more effective business processes in project processing and implementation; and 
(iii) further strengthen relationships with governments, institutions, and civil society in developing 
country safeguard systems and applying ADB safeguard policies. The TA outputs will be (i) an

4   
understanding  of  policy,  legislative,  and  institutional  gaps,  and  opportunities  in  DMCs  for 
improving country safeguard systems; (ii) identification of medium-term programs to strengthen 
country safeguard systems and capacities; (iii) harmonized approaches between ADB and 
development partners on the use of country systems in selected DMCs; and (iv) clear and 
consistent  operational  directions  on  safeguards  that  will  guide  the  development  and 
implementation of ADB projects. 
 
11.  Several  country  and  thematic  studies  are  needed  to  assess  the  commonalities  of 
safeguard  systems  in  selected  countries8  with  ADB  safeguard  policies.  Establishing  such 
commonalities  will  require  analyses  of  legal,  regulatory,  and  administrative  frameworks  at 
national,  subnational,  and  where  appropriate,  institutional  levels.  In  identifying  the 
commonalities or equivalence with ADB policies, practices, and institutional capacities, the 
studies will analyze gaps that require specific process improvements. The studies will involve 
reviews  of  experience  with  safeguards  in  selected  ADB-financed  projects,  sectors,  and 
institutions at national and subnational levels. By obtaining a clear picture of the status of 
safeguard applications, ADB can improve delivery of its policy and procedural requirements and 
deliver  the  benefits  of  its  development  interventions  more  effectively.  The  studies  will 
characterize countries at various levels and stages of safeguard planning and implementation 
capacities. The outputs of the studies and analyses will be reflected in ADB’s safeguard policy 
update being conducted in parallel, and the policy documentation will then be reviewed by a 
panel of internationally recognized safeguard experts. It is intended that the outputs will be 
consistent with middle-income country and IEI business processes. The TA will take a phased 
approach, with in-house reviews and discussions followed by consultations. A technical contact 
group will be established to review documentation and the TA’s progress.  
 
12.  Consultations  with  DMC  governments,  institutions,  civil  society  organizations,  and 
specialized nongovernment organizations will be a critical part of developing approaches to 
using country safeguard systems. The consultative process, which will be detailed by the time of 
inception, seeks to achieve as wide and appropriate a representation as possible at national 
and subregional levels. This is to ensure that debate and understanding are adequate for 
stakeholders  and  ADB.  Consultations  will  be  structured  around  (i)  presentations  on 
assessments of country safeguard systems and discussions on ADB’s safeguard policy update 
in  relation  to  improving  safeguard  applications,  (ii)  feedback  sessions  by  stakeholders  on 
policies and procedures relevant to the adoption of such systems, and (iii) documentation of                        
discussions that will then be posted on the web. The external consultative process will involve e-
mail exchanges and website discussions, for which a safeguard website has been developed 
that includes links to the three policies, OM sections, handbooks, and checklists. Consultation 
workshops are expected to take 1 or 2 days.  
 
13.  The consultative process will include (i) five subregional consultations; (ii) five or more 
country consultations (at least one from each of the five subregions, with close involvement of 
resident  missions);  and  (iii)  consultations  in  North  America,  Europe,  and  Japan.  Online 
consultations through the safeguard website and e-mail, as well as external expert consultations 
will run in parallel with the various consultation workshops.  
 
                                                 
8  The selection of countries will be based on the assessment of policy application and country safeguard capacity 
issues related to ADB-financed operations. Possible candidates are India, Indonesia, the Kyrgyz Republic, the 
Philippines, the PRC, and Viet Nam. ADB will request no-objection from the government of any selected country 
before implementing the TA in such country.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TA funding program. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  TA,  and  the  Environment  and  Social 
Safeguard Division (RSES) will be responsible for carrying out day-to-day activities under the 
TA.  ADB  will  recruit  international consultants  (safeguard  specialists  qualified  in  involuntary 
resettlement, environment, and indigenous peoples) for a total of 7.5 person-months to assess 
commonalities and review experience in the three areas. A panel of international experts for the 
three safeguards will be engaged as resource persons for 0.5 person-months each. Domestic 
consultants will be engaged in selected countries for 16 person-months to prepare background 
papers for specific project and institutional reviews. TA proceeds will be used to engage (i) a 
facilitator (international consultant) for the country and regional consultations, to help conduct 
workshops and prepare feedback and analytical documentation (7 person-months intermittently 
over 12 months); and (ii) technical support staff who specialize in outreach and communications 
and provide support for organizational arrangements for the studies and consultative processes 
(10  person-months).  All  consultants  will  be  engaged  as  individuals  in  accordance  with 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and Its Borrowers and other 
arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  Terms  of 
reference for international and domestic consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
16.  TA proceeds will be used to organize country consultations on the possible application of 
country systems and discussions on policy and procedural commonalities. This will be done in 
collaboration with governments, executing agencies, and civil society organizations (CSOs) in 
selected  countries.  ADB  will  organize  regional  consultations  to  cover  more  countries.  Civil 
society  representatives  will  be  invited.  ADB  will  selectively  finance  the  travel  and 
accommodation costs of participants who cannot afford to participate in the country and regional 
consultations.  
 
17.  The TA is expected to start in January 2006 and end by March 2007.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Country Safeguard Systems and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is initiating a regional technical assistance (TA) 
activity that will require detailed assessments of safeguard systems in developing member 
countries (DMCs). These assessments will identify areas of commonality and those in which 
complementarity will require capacity building, policy adaptation, and procedural clarity and 
definition. The emphasis will be on developing detailed characterization of safeguard systems 
within the selected countries using a typology of levels of preparedness and capacity. Given the 
wide differences in the levels of legal and institutional development in DMCs, the assessments 
should identify and analyze policy and procedural gaps in ADB safeguard policies. The key 
focus will be to establish how ADB can be responsive to changing circumstances in DMCs, and 
enable  DMCs  to  improve  their  own  safeguard  systems,  thereby  increasing  development 
investment opportunities and delivering benefits by minimizing social and environmental risks.  
 
2.  The TA is expected to (i) develop a methodological framework for applying a country 
safeguard systems approach under the overall framework of the safeguard policy update being 
carried out in parallel; (ii) identify practical approaches in developing more effective business 
processes; and (iii) strengthen relationships with governments, institutions, and civil society in 
developing country safeguard systems and applying ADB safeguard policies. 
 
3.  The TA will require the services of internationally recruited safeguard specialists and a 
panel of experts. They will assess country commonalities, review ADB experiences, and provide 
general advisory support to the ADB safeguard policy update in the Environment and Social 
Safeguard Division (RSES). The safeguard update will be led by RSES principal safeguard 
specialist, who will lead the team. Domestic consultants will carry out specific country and 
project review studies that will support the work of the international experts. 
 
A.  Safeguard Specialists and Panel of Experts 
 
  1.  Scope of Work 
 
4.  The safeguard specialists will be required to conduct country safeguard assessments in 
selected countries,1 review the impacts of ADB-funded projects, and help the team leader 
review  and  analyze  experiences.  This  will  enhance  the  effectiveness  of  ADB’s  safeguard 
policies, and keep those relevant to changing client needs and new lending modalities and 
instruments. The country and thematic studies are intended to identify commonalities of country 
safeguard systems with ADB safeguard policies. Establishing such commonalities will require 
analyses of legal, regulatory, and administrative frameworks at national, subnational, and where 
appropriate,  institutional  levels.  In  identifying  the  commonalities  or  equivalence  with  ADB 
policies, practices, and institutional capacities, the studies will analyze gaps that require specific 
process improvements. The studies will review experience with safeguards in selected ADB-
financed projects, sectors, and institutions at the national and subnational levels. This will 
provide a clear picture of the status of safeguard applications, which, in turn, will allow ADB to 
improve its policy and procedural requirements for delivering the benefits of its development 
interventions  more  effectively.  The  studies  will  establish  directions  for  safeguard  policies 
through detailed matrixes that characterize countries at various stages of safeguard planning 
and different levels of implementation capacity. The outcomes of the studies and analyses will

5.  The safeguard specialists will each have well-recognized credentials in environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples issues, particularly in Asia and the Pacific 
region, with experience in multilateral development bank operations. They will work closely with 
ADB’s environmental and indigenous peoples specialists. The panel of experts will (i) review the 
policy documentation created as an outcome of studies by the safeguard specialists, (ii) guide 
policy  directions,  and  (iii)  check  if  proposed  safeguard  policy  revisions  and  operational 
modifications are consistent with international norms and practices in safeguard applications. 
 
6.  The domestic consultants will be well qualified in environment, involuntary resettlement, 
and indigenous peoples issues, and have been involved in development activities financed by 
international organizations.  
 
  2.  Detailed Tasks 
 
7.  The safeguard specialists’ duties and responsibilities will consist of, but not necessarily 
be limited to, the following: 
 
(i)  preparing  country  safeguard  assessments  on  planning  and  implementing 
safeguard policies, and developing characterization matrixes that reflect stages 
of preparedness with respect to those safeguards at the national, subnational, 
and institutional levels; 
(ii)  reviewing safeguard policy application issues that arise during project planning 
and implementation and which might affect the quality and degree of compliance, 
and determining how these might be improved and/or integrated into the updated 
policy and new business processes;  
(iii)  preparing  reports  on  experiences  in  planning  and  implementing  safeguard 
policies in ADB-financed projects; 
(iv)  taking part in safeguard briefings and internal meetings; 
(v)  participating  in  country  and  regional  workshops  as  required,  and  preparing 
related reports; 
(vi)  reviewing safeguard issues associated with the application of country systems 
approaches; and  
(vii)  helping the team draft the updated safeguard policy and prepare draft operations 
manual sections and implementation guidelines for the policy.  
 
8.  The panel of experts, who will be internationally recognized in the three safeguard areas, 
will undertake the following, among other tasks that may be identified during the TA: 
 
(i)  reviewing policy documentation prepared as outcomes of the country safeguard 
assessments; 
(ii)  providing  expert  advice  on  safeguard  policy  and  operational  directions 
appropriate to ADB activities; and 
(iii)  providing guidance on consistency with internal norms and practices in safeguard 
applications.

B.  Consultative Process Facilitator 
 
  1.  Background and Objective 
 
12.  In view of the potential sensitivity of safeguard issues, the process will require significant 
consultation  and  consensus  building.  Consultation  will  be  internal  and  external  (with 
governments, development partners, and civil society, including nongovernment organizations 
[NGOs]), and will include expert panel reviews. 
 
13.  The  consultations  will  be  complex,  involving  agencies  and  institutions  with  different 
perspectives as well as diverse development interests and objectives. However, it is recognized 
that the groups share an interest in ensuring that development projects financed by ADB avoid 
or minimize adverse impacts, and that mitigative measures are developed and agreed upon with 
stakeholders, especially affected persons. External consultations will involve governments of 
developed  and  developing  countries,  NGOs,  multilaterals,  bilaterals,  and  agencies  and 
institutions that are closely involved in processing and implementing ADB-financed projects. The 
consultations  will  include  private  sector  representatives  who  are  involved  in  ADB-financed 
projects either directly or through financial intermediaries.  
 
  2.  Scope of Work 
 
14.  The facilitator will ensure the smooth organization of country and regional consultations, 
and any other meetings that may be required. The facilitator will accurately document the 
outcomes of the meetings and the positions of the participants, particularly NGOs and civil 
society representatives. The facilitator will help review exchanges and respond to queries raised 
by participants and civil society representatives. 
  
15.  The  facilitator  will  have  some  exposure  to  current  and  emerging  issues  related  to 
safeguard policies in country and international financing institutions. The facilitator should be

missions, acknowledging all responses received, and performing other tasks as 
directed by the team leader/director RSES; 
(iii)  participating in selected workshops as directed by the team leader/director RSES; 
(iv)  compiling, analyzing, and reporting on each workshop and on the cumulative 
results of all workshops; and 
(v)  supporting  associated  safeguard  policy  update  activities,  including  preparing

how they were addressed. 
 
  4.  Reporting Requirements and Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The assignment will be based in Manila, Philippines, and will require travel to DMCs as
